The Doctor was walking one day in Front
street, near Chesnut street, in the city OF
Philadelphia, at the dawn of the Revolution,
when he was thus accosted by Tar:


us your name Ben Franklin" Yes. "Are
you the man who invented the saw dust pud-
ding" Yes, replied the Doctor "Then,"
said the sailor, 'tor Gods sake don't give
the receipt to make it to old F., our
merchant, as he will feed all his crews on
it,


The story of the saw dust pudding, alter
dictum, wheat bran pudding, arose in this
manner. The Doctor had conducted an in
dependent paper in Philadelphia, which
gave offence to class who wanted to rule
every body in their own way; and the heads
of this party, some fifteen or twenty, in
formed the Doctor that they would frown
him down, unless he would submit to the
curb. The Doctor proposed to explain,
and fixed the time at his own house, where
the gentlemen were invited to dine. He re
quested his lady to employ two pence III the
purchase of peck of white bran, and to
make two puddings of it--one for each end
Of the table, as he was to have fifteen or
twenty friends. The company met-the
two puddings we're served on the table,
without any other dishes-the company sat
down, ana eaCh Irlela was selFeu WIN d
slice of pudding. Their curiosity led them
to try it--thcy examined each others coun-
tenances, and at length were satiated with
the pudding. Friends, said the Doctor, will
you be helped to mores No, they all replied,
we have enough of your pudding. But what
means this> Why, replied the Doctor, it
means that these two puddings cost two
perce, and fifteen friends say they have G.
ugh.-Know then, that as long as Benja-
min Franklin can satisfy fifteen friends with
two pence, he never will sacrifice the indie
pendence of his paper.
ANEcnorE oF FRANKLIN.

ny RICHARD PENN SMITH.
The mist Of the morn is still gray on the noun.


tain;
The heather bell blooms on the brink ofthe foun-


tain;
Soft murmurs the stream from the messy rock


gushing,
But wildly and loud through the dark ravine


rushing.
The heath-cock is sprngng elate from his nest;
The pale morn is sinking in calmness to rest;
The first streak of light is seen over the oceans
The chorister's songs put the dull air in motion.
The horn of the huntsman sounds far Ger the
The yoies ae'9s ST the feet hound is frequent and


shrI; -
While painting the chased stag appears at the


lake;
He swms the dark stream and then bounds


through the brake.
How sweet is the woodbinc DER yon lattice
creeping,
Which blushingly steals where the maiden IS


sleeping!
How softly the breeze sounds that kisses the bill.


low;
But softer by faris the sigh on yon pillow
The dash of the ligheeari is heard on the lake;
The soft voice of love sings, "Awake, oh awake;
The first streak ofmorning is gray ON the hill;
The voice of the barn-cock is frequent and shrlll.
"Then come, dearest come, where thy soul may


be free,
As the pure breeze that watts DER the margnhss


sea;
We'lsport in life's stream as we gently pass o'er
And feel not the breeze as we're gliding before


it."
The light form of one at the lattice is seen,
And ruby lips glow through the foliage of green,
Like bud of the vine the fresh breezes perfum-


ing,
Ere the breath of the morning has kiss'd it to


blooming
"Oh come, dearest come, to the cot Of thy lover,
Where souls may be free as the wings OF the plo-


yer,
And hearts be as pure as the vestal maids shrine,
And the day star oftlue love shall never decline.
The maiden now stands on the brink of the


stream,
And looks upon life as a f,irylike dreams
For she hcs to the spot where her soul may be


blest,
With passion as mild as the dove in its nest
On the stern of the skiff she is seated in haste,
Her lover beside her, with arm around her waist
He presses her lips as they Aoat from the shore,
And they mngle their songs with the dash of the


oar
With spirits as wild as the fawn at the fountain
they glide o'er the lake and then stroll up the


mountain,
Where the day star of true love in beauty is shin


ing,


And burns still more brightly as life is declining

From, The Philadephia album.
THE COTTAGE LOVERS.

to extend the benefits of my instruction; 1
should have civilized them, but savage,
whose distorted carcase no garment could
make straight, declared that such polished
tailors as were useless luxury i'll repub-
lie, and malevolently caused me to be ban
ished--this is the gratitude of republics!


returned to Crotona and set up shop;
throve, but, like good patriot, my heart
yearned for my native land. thought | had
punished it enough A citizen of Crotena
had occasion to go upon a journey; knowing
my extreme virtue, he deposited his gold in
my hands. Before he returned, All oppor-
tunity offered to me of going into Egypt; !
went, but in the hurry Of my departure tor
got to leave the gold behind: the trash new
er entered into my mind. recollected it
when | arrived into Egypt, and literally
distributed it among the wretches who cal
led themselves my creditors | laid an ac-
count of my noble actions before the king,
but the king inclined to the advice of his
evil counsellors, and would not listen to me
to me who had saved his thronc-such is
the munlieence of kings.


Abandoned, neglected, plundered and
trodden down by all, was obliged to drudge
at my trade till my death, and now am bu-
ried without a monument. | who have
taught geometry to the Egyptians-van-
+, quished the Ethiopians; civilized the Greeks
and Romans, and been crowned conqueror
at the Olympic games, lie Mere in COM
mon mummy pit!

She spoke Of love--and round her lips
A glowing sunbeam scem'd to plays
Yet DER it hung dark eclipse,


Ready to dim its trembling ray.
As stars shine in their azure spheres,


And pour out soft eifulgency,
So richly shone her virgin tears,


MISUNDERSTANDING silently.
She sung oflovc-and with voice


That partly lngerd on her tongue;
Methoug ght choir Of paradise


Mingled their no;cs with those she sung,
Aso'er til, wilder'd chords she swept,


Such music through the ether few.
That when the pensiye minstrel wept,


could not keep from weeping too.
She dicd for love--and with breath


That rose like incense pure above,
Yielded her angel-torm to death


Though to the last she spoke OF love!
80, thus it is, +" cried, as by


Her silent urn wept alone,
"That bcauty's flower is sure to die,


"Whcn budding meath too warm sun"

The reader has frequently heard this rev.

bly, his name may have outlived his maneu

olnderthe sway of Henry VIII, and Protes-

gain under Queen Mary, and again Pro-
testant under Queen Elizabeth. When this
snoal ireouan, TO the gown was reProachea tor his
s"er: II cannot help that; but if I changed
My religion, am sure | kept true to my
principle, which is: to live and die Vicar o
sray.'' "

Those who make religion to consist in the
contempt of this world and its enJoyments
are under very fatal and dangerous mis-
take. AS life is the gift Of heaven, it is Re-
ligion to enjoy it. He. therefore, who can
be happy in himself, and who contributes
all that is in his power towards the happi-
ness Of others, and none but the vrtuous can
so be and so do. answers most effectually the
end OF his creation, is an honor to his nature
and pattern to mankind.

A watchmaker of Bayreuth has manufac-
tured cage filled with birds, to the num-
ber of sixty, representing parrots, sparrows,
swallows, &C., each of which has the pecu-
liar note given by nature. The cageis made
of brass. and the wheels which make them
move. and produce the sound are silver; the
plumage is real. A person of distinction, it
appears, offered the matchmaker 81, 900 aor-
ins for his cage, but he will not take less
than $4,000.
EXQUISITE MACHINE.

| In Paris new periodical work has recent.
ly been established, called the Reuue .4meri-
came, which is devoted to intelligence and
particulars relating to this country. One Of
the numbers contains an extract from Mr..
lie Vassieur's Journal of Lafay tour
mong the Greek Indians. It is written with
SO much simplicity and spirit, that we can
not doubt the following translation will be
highly acceptable to our readers.


"Macon, pretty little town, which is now
tolerably well peopled, was not in existence
eighteen months ago. 1t seems to have aris.
Ell from the forests as by enchantment. 1t
is civil spot, lost amid the still immense
domains of thu first children Of America.
About league thence we are in the bosom
of virgin forests, and the tops of the trees
which seem as old as the world hang over
our heads. The winds sounded through
them by turns grave and shrill which M.
de Ch4teaubriand calls the voice of the des-
ert Our road was a sort of trench, at the
bottom of which the carriage of the Gener-
al rolled with difficulty, and was often in
dlnger of breaking. We followed on horse
back and thus arrived at the Indian Agen-
cy.


This is situated in the midst OF forests,
contructed for the convenience ot the Indian
| Chiefs and the Agents of the United States,
who hold their conference there. 1t was
there that the treaty was formed, after
Which the Indian tribes still inhabitants of
the left branch of the Missouri, consented
for considerable sum, to retire to the right.
The wear 1897 was assigned for their evacu-
alton. and it is not without pain that the In
dians see this conclusion of their ancient
/ Nbax, tutf \, AZ
the neighborhooel of civilized men notwith-
standing they dislike them. They accuse
their chiefs Of having betrayed them in max
ing this cession, and we are assured, that ii
has already cost the life of Macintosh, one
of the slgners of the treaty.


We passed the night at the Indian Agen
ev--the habitatinn was deserted. For fifty
wears the name of General Lafayette had
| lived among them by tradition, and an hun
dred Indians had waited to receive us; but
the delays which we experienced during oul
rout having tired their patience, they had
gone elsewhere to prepare reception. We
had 10 travel tfirty-two miles the next day
by roote still less practicable--Such g
storm as we have never seen in England


and which however do not wish to describe
assaied us and dispersed us during some


hours. Very happily we met with shelter


it was cabin raised by an American, moi


far from our road. Some Indian hunters


probably in the habit Of taking shelter there


were driving their clothing around large
fire. at which we took our place without be
ing known, and without attracting grea
deal Of attention. Mime, on the contrary


WAS very strongly excited by this meeting
the first, had had Of the kind. had heari


so much of these children OF nature, and hav
ing only lived in civilized country, hae


formed such singular ideas about them tina


the least of their gestures, the smalles
piece of their clothing or armour, excited II


me almost as much astonishment, as the In


dans in return seemed to feel upon seeins


us. As far as the language Of signs permit


ted | put to them number of questions
which they answered by pantomine at ono


expressive and laconic.


The immobilty Of the Indians has heel
mentioned to me as natural faculty, which


is sngularly increased in them by education


wished to have some experience upon th
point, not knowing how they would take it.


provoked one of them by some hostile
signs. hue-my anger though very well te'gn


ed, did not move him any more than the


play of a child. He continued his conversa'
ton without regarding me and without ex


messing either fear or disdain. After some
trials Of the same kind, and always met will
! the same imperturbable calmness, ! return
ed again to signs of kindness. offered te
, the Indians my gourd fullof brandy. Tha
succeeded better. They emptied il; show
ed them some pieces OF silver in my hand


and they took them away without ceremo


nv. Quilted them soon, ard it appeared tt
me that we parted good friends.

From the Baltimore Patriot,
JOURNEY OF LAFAyETTE
TIE COUNTRY OF THE CREE


INDIANS

Geatilny.-If gcntility be virtue, who
ever is not yrtuous loses his title, and it it is
not virtue it is trihc.-I6id.

again, and begin our route. We arrived at
habltation a little better than that of the
watch. 1t was group of cabins construct
ed with the bodies of ftrecs placed over each
other and stripped of their bark-The host
was an American, who by reverse of for
tune had been forced to take refuge in this
place, where he made a pretty lucrative
commerce, exchanging fur skins furnished
by the Indians for commodities brought from
the civilized countries. His little farm was
composed of some we'll cultivated acres, of
well furnished poultry yard, and the habi-
tation have described. At our arrival we
found two Indians seated before the door,
one young, the other grown up man, and
both Of remarkable form and beauty. They
were clothed with short tunic of light and
tringed stuff, fastened round their bodies by
girdle embroidered with small beads of
thousand colors-A shawl oflively color was
rolled round their heads with much ele-
gance. Their trowsers of sheep skins reached
down to their knees. They rose at the ap-
proach of the general, saluted him, and the
Youngest, to our great astonishment, compl-
mented him in very good English. We soon
learned that he had passed his youth in .
college in the United Sta, es, but that he had
stolen away many years ago from benefac-
tor to return to his brothers, whose life he
preferred to that of civilized men. The
General put many questions to him upon the
existence of the Indian colony. He replied
TO them with much sense and precision
When he was questioned as to the last trea-
ty concluded with the United States, his


countenance darkened, he struck his foot


on the grountl, and laying hold of the handle
of his knife, he mentioned the name of Mac
Intosh, in a manner which made US shuddcr


at the danger oe this chief. As we appear


ed Observation-Disclosures cried he, "has


sold the land of his fathers-He has sacrifice


ed us all to his ayarice-It is impossible to
break the treaty which he has formed; but
the scoundrel!" He stopped after this vi
olent exclamation, and little while after
took up quietly some other subject OF con-
versation.


Hatnly Chat was the name of the young
Indian) when he saw US little rested, en-
gagged us to visit his habitation, which We
perceived on the brow Of hill at a little dis
tance. Two of the Generals Aids-de camps,
and myself accepted the invitation, and we
followed the Indians-Going along he show
cd US an inclosure surrounded with palisades
filled with stays, mastiifs, and grey hounds,
which they called their reserpe, and which
supplied them, when the chase proved un-
favorable. Hamley's cabin bordered upon
this enclosure We entered lt--There was


great fire in the Fireplace, the day was


declining, and the spacious habitation was


lighted bv the flame of the fir tree. The


furniture was composed of table. two beds,
some large chairs, ozier baskets, fire arms,


bows and arrows were hung upon the wall,


and also violin. The arrangement OF all


indicated the presence of a halt civilized man.
I The companion of Hamly took down the VIII


olin and managing the fiddle stick with more


strength than lightness, played some parts


of an Indian air, which Immediately gave
/ iIamly inclination to dance; but whether


from courtesy, or from desire of making


comparison which was to his advantage, he


begged us to dance first, in the manner of


our country. The grave Americans who


accompanied me declined-younger or less


reserved than they, did not wait to be ask


ed twice; and performed some OF our dull


French dances. Hamlv asked no more,


saw him throw off what embarrassed him,


seize great shawl and spring triumphantly
into the midst OF the room, as if he had said,


s.Ths scene is for mel retired to leave


the field to him. His first movements, slow


and with feeling, became animated by de-


grees; his dance incomparably more vio-
lent and more expressive than our opera


dances was soon only whirlwind which
the eve could not follow. In the intervals


in which he stopped to take breath; his


steps became gradually slower; his head fell


gently and followed gracefully the move


ments of his supple body, and his eyes


were brilliant with an emotion which height


ened the copper color of his complexion,-


The cries which escaped from him in rous-
ing up from this reverie to recommence his
lively movements. had an unexpected effect
upon us, which it is difficult to describe.


Two Indian women who | afterwards


learned were Hamly's wives, approached


the habitation, whilst it resounded with the
sports of .mly and his applauses. but they
did not enter, alone perceived them
They had the beauty peculiar to their race;
their vestment was composed OF long White
tunic; of scarlet drapery thrown over their
shoulders, their long hair leated at liberty
they carried upon their necks collar of
four or five rings of pearls, and in their ears
enormous pendants of silver which are the
nrinrinaI ornaments of Indian women. I
thought BY their reserve that Hamly had


forbid them to approach us, and l could not
even put any question concerning them.--


There were some negroes in the cabin of the
Young Indian; but they did not appear to me
i, to be in the condition of slavcs--.hey were


furitives to whom be had given an asylum,
and who paid his hospitality with their Ia

Whenc er hear that screaming ditty,
| think ottortur'd slaves with pity,
Offelons dragged in rusty gives,
Of Ofsqueaking pigs and scoldIng wives.


introduction 10 Cholmer's pale Of fChamoani.

The love of Gaming is the worst ills,
With chaseless storms the blacken'd soul it


fills,
lnveghs at Heay'n, neglects the ties ofbood
DESTROYS the power and will Of doing good


grace
And what is still more dreadful--spoils your


face.
GAMING.

in the city of Memphis /.


When | reflect on the avarice and in
gratitude of my countrymen, and the base
ness and perfdity of other nations my heart
so swells with hatred to the world, that, in
order to punish human nature, feel almost
resolved to be inferred without single me-
mortal of who or what was, but the recol-
lection of posterity sottens my anger-pos-
terity, for whom have labored has done
me no wrong; and in order that it may still
benefit by my advice, have composed this
paper to warn it how it trusts to kings, re-
publcs, philosophers or barbarians.


was a tailor in the reign of King Psar
manthis, and never did tailor work on more
| scientific principles; it was ! who first APP
piled geometry to cutting out, and it was
from me that the husbandmen first learnt to
lay out their fields and ascertain their boun-
daries after the nundaton of the Nile, and
they endeayored to cut up the face of the
earth, by the rules had established for cut
! ting out garment; but, unlike me, each of
the knaves attempted to cabbage as much of
| his neighbours ground as possible; for used
all my mathematical precision as much to
my customers advantage as to my own.


The fashions projected were elegant and
innumerable, quite reformed the taste ct
the age, men looked like crocodiles before
took them in hand, but made them look
/ like demi gods; may say without vanity,
that possessed a greater genius than vas
ever given to man, or than nan will ever
again be gifted with. for ! united the cor
rcctncss Of the playful and excursive fancy
of the poet; was the perpetual source OF all
elegance, dignity, beauty--and after all,
am neglected and buried in common mum
my pitt


| The advantages my country derived from
my talents were not restricted to the refne'
ment of the human shape or the just setting
out OF boundaries. Our armies had been de-
featcd in several campaigns by the Ethiopi-
ans; new general was appointed who was
customer of mine, he engaged the enemy
dressed in garment OF my construction:
need not say he utterly routed them. had
compounded his coat so terrihcally that no
troops could stand against it--Yet was
| ineglected--he was enri he'd, but was not
4 rewarded-and he even had the horrible IN
gratitude to dispute my bill


A feet was fitted out to explore tie way
to India--lt tailcd--Anothcr was despatch
cd and returned without success. A third
was ordered to make the attempt, and con
tracted for clothing the sailors in an admi-
ral's galley. 1t would be unnecessary for
me to say that this expedition was fortunate.
Were rowers likely to fail, drest in garments
of my own fashionings


! A travelling Greek took lodging in my
house. He called himself philosopher,
voyagng in search of knowledge. am
certain it was by seeing me cut out gore
that he learned the square of the hypothe-
muse Of a right angled triangle is equal othe
squares of the base and pendlcuar added
together, for it cannot be doubted for mo-
lment that knew il. Yet the vagabond had
the audacity to assert that he had made the
discovery by the inspiration OF the muses.,
and offered whole hecatomb in canse-
aucncc, while he seliishly concea'ed my
name altogether. Thus the invention, to
which had so we'll founded right, will be
handed down to after ages as the discovery
of Greek vagrant, while |, who ought IN
consequence to have been buried IN the
great pyramid, am shutiled into a paltry
sycamore coffin in common mummy PIT


was walking with this Greek one day,
when saw an Ibis with peculiarly long
bill mrhat IBIS" said ], "looks like my
grandmother, who had very long nose. =
The scoundrelly philosopher took the hlnt
"Your grandmother's SOUL" said he, "has
transmierated into that Ibis; recollect hay,
inc been goose myself was Euphorbus in
the Trojan war" And upon this ebserva-
ton of mine, he built his theory of transmit
grafton. Yet he chose rather to say that ht
learnt it from the Chaldeans or Brachmans
than from me-such is the gratitude of phi
losophers
was not fitted to thrive amidst greedy
selfish, narrsw minded, avaricious race
except myself. there was no honorable mar
in Epypt. The base knaves took advantage
of nv excellent disposition. nv noble gene.
rosity, my astonishing libcrality, my exalted
virtue, and defrauded me. | resolved tt
quit such nest of crocotiles, and made {
dignifed retreat during the night. that
nv purpose might not be frustrated, dis
guised myself as an humble slave, and ac-
companied the ungrateful philosopher as :
servant. My base minded countrymen, ind
ing was out of their reach, vented theil
sorrow in the most horrible .calumnies, ane
said fed for debt. did indeed owe some
individuals money, which did not think i
convenient to pay, but if that was set on a.
rainst the endless debt my country owed t
me. the balance would be found immensely


in my favour.


went with this philosophical quack t.
his native city of Samos: there | clyillzet
the barbarous sIanders---they knew nothing
of fashionable dress till | taught them
From thence accompanied him to Croto
ma; there humanized the people Of Italy
from savages made them one OF the poilt

full articles.headline: ANEcnorE oF FRANKLIN.
full articles.article:
The Doctor was walking one day in Front
street, near Chesnut street, in the city OF
Philadelphia, at the dawn of the Revolution,
when he was thus accosted by Tar:


us your name Ben Franklin" Yes. "Are
you the man who invented the saw dust pud-
ding" Yes, replied the Doctor "Then,"
said the sailor, 'tor Gods sake don't give
the receipt to make it to old F., our
merchant, as he will feed all his crews on
it,


The story of the saw dust pudding, alter
dictum, wheat bran pudding, arose in this
manner. The Doctor had conducted an in
dependent paper in Philadelphia, which
gave offence to class who wanted to rule
every body in their own way; and the heads
of this party, some fifteen or twenty, in
formed the Doctor that they would frown
him down, unless he would submit to the
curb. The Doctor proposed to explain,
and fixed the time at his own house, where
the gentlemen were invited to dine. He re
quested his lady to employ two pence III the
purchase of peck of white bran, and to
make two puddings of it--one for each end
Of the table, as he was to have fifteen or
twenty friends. The company met-the
two puddings we're served on the table,
without any other dishes-the company sat
down, ana eaCh Irlela was selFeu WIN d
slice of pudding. Their curiosity led them
to try it--thcy examined each others coun-
tenances, and at length were satiated with
the pudding. Friends, said the Doctor, will
you be helped to mores No, they all replied,
we have enough of your pudding. But what
means this> Why, replied the Doctor, it
means that these two puddings cost two
perce, and fifteen friends say they have G.
ugh.-Know then, that as long as Benja-
min Franklin can satisfy fifteen friends with
two pence, he never will sacrifice the indie
pendence of his paper.

tain;
Soft murmurs the stream from the messy rock


gushing,
But wildly and loud through the dark ravine


rushing.
The heath-cock is sprngng elate from his nest;
The pale morn is sinking in calmness to rest;
The first streak of light is seen over the oceans
The chorister's songs put the dull air in motion.
The horn of the huntsman sounds far Ger the
The yoies ae'9s ST the feet hound is frequent and


shrI; -
While painting the chased stag appears at the


lake;
He swms the dark stream and then bounds


through the brake.
How sweet is the woodbinc DER yon lattice
creeping,
Which blushingly steals where the maiden IS


sleeping!
How softly the breeze sounds that kisses the bill.


low;
But softer by faris the sigh on yon pillow
The dash of the ligheeari is heard on the lake;
The soft voice of love sings, "Awake, oh awake;
The first streak ofmorning is gray ON the hill;
The voice of the barn-cock is frequent and shrlll.
"Then come, dearest come, where thy soul may


be free,
As the pure breeze that watts DER the margnhss


sea;
We'lsport in life's stream as we gently pass o'er
And feel not the breeze as we're gliding before


it."
The light form of one at the lattice is seen,
And ruby lips glow through the foliage of green,
Like bud of the vine the fresh breezes perfum-


ing,
Ere the breath of the morning has kiss'd it to


blooming
"Oh come, dearest come, to the cot Of thy lover,
Where souls may be free as the wings OF the plo-


yer,
And hearts be as pure as the vestal maids shrine,
And the day star oftlue love shall never decline.
The maiden now stands on the brink of the


stream,
And looks upon life as a f,irylike dreams
For she hcs to the spot where her soul may be


blest,
With passion as mild as the dove in its nest
On the stern of the skiff she is seated in haste,
Her lover beside her, with arm around her waist
He presses her lips as they Aoat from the shore,
And they mngle their songs with the dash of the


oar
With spirits as wild as the fawn at the fountain
they glide o'er the lake and then stroll up the


mountain,
Where the day star of true love in beauty is shin


ing,


And burns still more brightly as life is declining

to extend the benefits of my instruction; 1
should have civilized them, but savage,
whose distorted carcase no garment could
make straight, declared that such polished
tailors as were useless luxury i'll repub-
lie, and malevolently caused me to be ban
ished--this is the gratitude of republics!


returned to Crotona and set up shop;
throve, but, like good patriot, my heart
yearned for my native land. thought | had
punished it enough A citizen of Crotena
had occasion to go upon a journey; knowing
my extreme virtue, he deposited his gold in
my hands. Before he returned, All oppor-
tunity offered to me of going into Egypt; !
went, but in the hurry Of my departure tor
got to leave the gold behind: the trash new
er entered into my mind. recollected it
when | arrived into Egypt, and literally
distributed it among the wretches who cal
led themselves my creditors | laid an ac-
count of my noble actions before the king,
but the king inclined to the advice of his
evil counsellors, and would not listen to me
to me who had saved his thronc-such is
the munlieence of kings.


Abandoned, neglected, plundered and
trodden down by all, was obliged to drudge
at my trade till my death, and now am bu-
ried without a monument. | who have
taught geometry to the Egyptians-van-
+, quished the Ethiopians; civilized the Greeks
and Romans, and been crowned conqueror
at the Olympic games, lie Mere in COM
mon mummy pit!

full articles.headline:
.PD-HzII21Ys .

SHE DIED OF LOVE.
full articles.article:
She spoke Of love--and round her lips
A glowing sunbeam scem'd to plays
Yet DER it hung dark eclipse,


Ready to dim its trembling ray.
As stars shine in their azure spheres,


And pour out soft eifulgency,
So richly shone her virgin tears,


MISUNDERSTANDING silently.
She sung oflovc-and with voice


That partly lngerd on her tongue;
Methoug ght choir Of paradise


Mingled their no;cs with those she sung,
Aso'er til, wilder'd chords she swept,


Such music through the ether few.
That when the pensiye minstrel wept,


could not keep from weeping too.
She dicd for love--and with breath


That rose like incense pure above,
Yielded her angel-torm to death


Though to the last she spoke OF love!
80, thus it is, +" cried, as by


Her silent urn wept alone,
"That bcauty's flower is sure to die,


"Whcn budding meath too warm sun"

full articles.headline:
THE AUrO-BIOGRAPIIY OF flilMB!Ot


THE son OF OcuuNAs THE EGYPrIAN,
full articles.article:
Where is the brain that imagined great and
noble actons' Yea its place is filed with spi-
ces and oderifcrous gums. Where IS the hand
that slew monsters and overthrow armies The
swathings of fine linen bind il fast, 1t cannot
move. The Poet Pemayroh.


Ye who find relief amid the pains of life
in the hope of being buried in splendid
tomb, listen with attention to the laIhenta-
tions of Thimblou the son of Ochonas. 1t
knowledge, wisdom, or virtue, could insure
a pyramid, l have deserved one; it life OF
labor spent in the service ofmy fellow men
could acquire sarcophagus covered with
hieroglyphics. ought to be laid in one OF
the most splendid description, for l have
carried the arts of Egypt to the barbarians
of the west-I have conquered armies once
deemed invincible--I have civilized foreign

full articles.headline:
COLLCT ANEA.

THE VICAR oF BRAY.
full articles.article:
The reader has frequently heard this rev.
erend son of the church mentioned proba-
bly, his name may have outlived his maneu
vres to keep possession Of his benefce. The
Vicar of Bray, in Berk shire, was a Papist
olnderthe sway of Henry VIII, and Protes-
'ant under Edward vi; he was Papist a
gain under Queen Mary, and again Pro-
testant under Queen Elizabeth. When this
snoal ireouan, TO the gown was reProachea tor his
s"er: II cannot help that; but if I changed
My religion, am sure | kept true to my
principle, which is: to live and die Vicar o
sray.'' "

full articles.headline: RELIGION
full articles.article:
Those who make religion to consist in the
contempt of this world and its enJoyments
are under very fatal and dangerous mis-
take. AS life is the gift Of heaven, it is Re-
ligion to enjoy it. He. therefore, who can
be happy in himself, and who contributes
all that is in his power towards the happi-
ness Of others, and none but the vrtuous can
so be and so do. answers most effectually the
end OF his creation, is an honor to his nature
and pattern to mankind.

full articles.headline: EXQUISITE MACHINE.
full articles.article:
A watchmaker of Bayreuth has manufac-
tured cage filled with birds, to the num-
ber of sixty, representing parrots, sparrows,
swallows, &C., each of which has the pecu-
liar note given by nature. The cageis made
of brass. and the wheels which make them
move. and produce the sound are silver; the
plumage is real. A person of distinction, it
appears, offered the matchmaker 81, 900 aor-
ins for his cage, but he will not take less
than $4,000.

OATIIS.
In every tale they tell, or false or true,
We'll known, or such as no man ever knew,
They fix attention, needless fyour pain,
With oaths like rivets farced into the brains
And cen when sober truth prevails throughout,
They swear, it till affirmative breeds q doubt


Cowper's Conversation.

full articles.headline: EXTRAyAGANCE.
full articles.article:
1t is reported of Plato, that seeing once a
young spendthrift eating bread and water at
the door of an inn, where he had squander-
ed his estate, the philosopher could not help
saying, young man, if you had dncd mod
eratcly, you need not have supped SO poor
ly."

full articles.headline:
From the Baltimore Patriot,
JOURNEY OF LAFAyETTE
TIE COUNTRY OF THE CREE


INDIANS
full articles.article:
| In Paris new periodical work has recent.
ly been established, called the Reuue .4meri-
came, which is devoted to intelligence and
particulars relating to this country. One Of
the numbers contains an extract from Mr..
lie Vassieur's Journal of Lafay tour
mong the Greek Indians. It is written with
SO much simplicity and spirit, that we can
not doubt the following translation will be
highly acceptable to our readers.


"Macon, pretty little town, which is now
tolerably well peopled, was not in existence
eighteen months ago. 1t seems to have aris.
Ell from the forests as by enchantment. 1t
is civil spot, lost amid the still immense
domains of thu first children Of America.
About league thence we are in the bosom
of virgin forests, and the tops of the trees
which seem as old as the world hang over
our heads. The winds sounded through
them by turns grave and shrill which M.
de Ch4teaubriand calls the voice of the des-
ert Our road was a sort of trench, at the
bottom of which the carriage of the Gener-
al rolled with difficulty, and was often in
dlnger of breaking. We followed on horse
back and thus arrived at the Indian Agen-
cy.


This is situated in the midst OF forests,
contructed for the convenience ot the Indian
| Chiefs and the Agents of the United States,
who hold their conference there. 1t was
there that the treaty was formed, after
Which the Indian tribes still inhabitants of
the left branch of the Missouri, consented
for considerable sum, to retire to the right.
The wear 1897 was assigned for their evacu-
alton. and it is not without pain that the In
dians see this conclusion of their ancient
/ Nbax, tutf \, AZ
the neighborhooel of civilized men notwith-
standing they dislike them. They accuse
their chiefs Of having betrayed them in max
ing this cession, and we are assured, that ii
has already cost the life of Macintosh, one
of the slgners of the treaty.


We passed the night at the Indian Agen
ev--the habitatinn was deserted. For fifty
wears the name of General Lafayette had
| lived among them by tradition, and an hun
dred Indians had waited to receive us; but
the delays which we experienced during oul
rout having tired their patience, they had
gone elsewhere to prepare reception. We
had 10 travel tfirty-two miles the next day
by roote still less practicable--Such g
storm as we have never seen in England


and which however do not wish to describe
assaied us and dispersed us during some


hours. Very happily we met with shelter


it was cabin raised by an American, moi


far from our road. Some Indian hunters


probably in the habit Of taking shelter there


were driving their clothing around large
fire. at which we took our place without be
ing known, and without attracting grea
deal Of attention. Mime, on the contrary


WAS very strongly excited by this meeting
the first, had had Of the kind. had heari


so much of these children OF nature, and hav
ing only lived in civilized country, hae


formed such singular ideas about them tina


the least of their gestures, the smalles
piece of their clothing or armour, excited II


me almost as much astonishment, as the In


dans in return seemed to feel upon seeins


us. As far as the language Of signs permit


ted | put to them number of questions
which they answered by pantomine at ono


expressive and laconic.


The immobilty Of the Indians has heel
mentioned to me as natural faculty, which


is sngularly increased in them by education


wished to have some experience upon th
point, not knowing how they would take it.


provoked one of them by some hostile
signs. hue-my anger though very well te'gn


ed, did not move him any more than the


play of a child. He continued his conversa'
ton without regarding me and without ex


messing either fear or disdain. After some
trials Of the same kind, and always met will
! the same imperturbable calmness, ! return
ed again to signs of kindness. offered te
, the Indians my gourd fullof brandy. Tha
succeeded better. They emptied il; show
ed them some pieces OF silver in my hand


and they took them away without ceremo


nv. Quilted them soon, ard it appeared tt
me that we parted good friends.


|, The err: ftfe storm permitted rat2 nee

Geatilny.-If gcntility be virtue, who
ever is not yrtuous loses his title, and it it is
not virtue it is trihc.-I6id.

again, and begin our route. We arrived at
habltation a little better than that of the
watch. 1t was group of cabins construct
ed with the bodies of ftrecs placed over each
other and stripped of their bark-The host
was an American, who by reverse of for
tune had been forced to take refuge in this
place, where he made a pretty lucrative
commerce, exchanging fur skins furnished
by the Indians for commodities brought from
the civilized countries. His little farm was
composed of some we'll cultivated acres, of
well furnished poultry yard, and the habi-
tation have described. At our arrival we
found two Indians seated before the door,
one young, the other grown up man, and
both Of remarkable form and beauty. They
were clothed with short tunic of light and
tringed stuff, fastened round their bodies by
girdle embroidered with small beads of
thousand colors-A shawl oflively color was
rolled round their heads with much ele-
gance. Their trowsers of sheep skins reached
down to their knees. They rose at the ap-
proach of the general, saluted him, and the
Youngest, to our great astonishment, compl-
mented him in very good English. We soon
learned that he had passed his youth in .
college in the United Sta, es, but that he had
stolen away many years ago from benefac-
tor to return to his brothers, whose life he
preferred to that of civilized men. The
General put many questions to him upon the
existence of the Indian colony. He replied
TO them with much sense and precision
When he was questioned as to the last trea-
ty concluded with the United States, his


countenance darkened, he struck his foot


on the grountl, and laying hold of the handle
of his knife, he mentioned the name of Mac
Intosh, in a manner which made US shuddcr


at the danger oe this chief. As we appear


ed Observation-Disclosures cried he, "has


sold the land of his fathers-He has sacrifice


ed us all to his ayarice-It is impossible to
break the treaty which he has formed; but
the scoundrel!" He stopped after this vi
olent exclamation, and little while after
took up quietly some other subject OF con-
versation.


Hatnly Chat was the name of the young
Indian) when he saw US little rested, en-
gagged us to visit his habitation, which We
perceived on the brow Of hill at a little dis
tance. Two of the Generals Aids-de camps,
and myself accepted the invitation, and we
followed the Indians-Going along he show
cd US an inclosure surrounded with palisades
filled with stays, mastiifs, and grey hounds,
which they called their reserpe, and which
supplied them, when the chase proved un-
favorable. Hamley's cabin bordered upon
this enclosure We entered lt--There was


great fire in the Fireplace, the day was


declining, and the spacious habitation was


lighted bv the flame of the fir tree. The


furniture was composed of table. two beds,
some large chairs, ozier baskets, fire arms,


bows and arrows were hung upon the wall,


and also violin. The arrangement OF all


indicated the presence of a halt civilized man.
I The companion of Hamly took down the VIII


olin and managing the fiddle stick with more


strength than lightness, played some parts


of an Indian air, which Immediately gave
/ iIamly inclination to dance; but whether


from courtesy, or from desire of making


comparison which was to his advantage, he


begged us to dance first, in the manner of


our country. The grave Americans who


accompanied me declined-younger or less


reserved than they, did not wait to be ask


ed twice; and performed some OF our dull


French dances. Hamlv asked no more,


saw him throw off what embarrassed him,


seize great shawl and spring triumphantly
into the midst OF the room, as if he had said,


s.Ths scene is for mel retired to leave


the field to him. His first movements, slow


and with feeling, became animated by de-


grees; his dance incomparably more vio-
lent and more expressive than our opera


dances was soon only whirlwind which
the eve could not follow. In the intervals


in which he stopped to take breath; his


steps became gradually slower; his head fell


gently and followed gracefully the move


ments of his supple body, and his eyes


were brilliant with an emotion which height


ened the copper color of his complexion,-


The cries which escaped from him in rous-
ing up from this reverie to recommence his
lively movements. had an unexpected effect
upon us, which it is difficult to describe.


Two Indian women who | afterwards


learned were Hamly's wives, approached


the habitation, whilst it resounded with the
sports of .mly and his applauses. but they
did not enter, alone perceived them
They had the beauty peculiar to their race;
their vestment was composed OF long White
tunic; of scarlet drapery thrown over their
shoulders, their long hair leated at liberty
they carried upon their necks collar of
four or five rings of pearls, and in their ears
enormous pendants of silver which are the
nrinrinaI ornaments of Indian women. I
thought BY their reserve that Hamly had


forbid them to approach us, and l could not
even put any question concerning them.--


There were some negroes in the cabin of the
Young Indian; but they did not appear to me
i, to be in the condition of slavcs--.hey were


furitives to whom be had given an asylum,
and who paid his hospitality with their Ia

full articles.headline: BAuPlpEs.
full articles.article:
Whenc er hear that screaming ditty,
| think ottortur'd slaves with pity,
Offelons dragged in rusty gives,
Of Ofsqueaking pigs and scoldIng wives.


introduction 10 Cholmer's pale Of fChamoani.

full articles.headline: GAMING.
full articles.article:
The love of Gaming is the worst ills,
With chaseless storms the blacken'd soul it


fills,
lnveghs at Heay'n, neglects the ties ofbood
DESTROYS the power and will Of doing good


grace
And what is still more dreadful--spoils your


face.

full articles.headline: MARCH Is, 1927
full articles.article:
in the city of Memphis /.


When | reflect on the avarice and in
gratitude of my countrymen, and the base
ness and perfdity of other nations my heart
so swells with hatred to the world, that, in
order to punish human nature, feel almost
resolved to be inferred without single me-
mortal of who or what was, but the recol-
lection of posterity sottens my anger-pos-
terity, for whom have labored has done
me no wrong; and in order that it may still
benefit by my advice, have composed this
paper to warn it how it trusts to kings, re-
publcs, philosophers or barbarians.


was a tailor in the reign of King Psar
manthis, and never did tailor work on more
| scientific principles; it was ! who first APP
piled geometry to cutting out, and it was
from me that the husbandmen first learnt to
lay out their fields and ascertain their boun-
daries after the nundaton of the Nile, and
they endeayored to cut up the face of the
earth, by the rules had established for cut
! ting out garment; but, unlike me, each of
the knaves attempted to cabbage as much of
| his neighbours ground as possible; for used
all my mathematical precision as much to
my customers advantage as to my own.


The fashions projected were elegant and
innumerable, quite reformed the taste ct
the age, men looked like crocodiles before
took them in hand, but made them look
/ like demi gods; may say without vanity,
that possessed a greater genius than vas
ever given to man, or than nan will ever
again be gifted with. for ! united the cor
rcctncss Of the playful and excursive fancy
of the poet; was the perpetual source OF all
elegance, dignity, beauty--and after all,
am neglected and buried in common mum
my pitt


| The advantages my country derived from
my talents were not restricted to the refne'
ment of the human shape or the just setting
out OF boundaries. Our armies had been de-
featcd in several campaigns by the Ethiopi-
ans; new general was appointed who was
customer of mine, he engaged the enemy
dressed in garment OF my construction:
need not say he utterly routed them. had
compounded his coat so terrihcally that no
troops could stand against it--Yet was
| ineglected--he was enri he'd, but was not
4 rewarded-and he even had the horrible IN
gratitude to dispute my bill


A feet was fitted out to explore tie way
to India--lt tailcd--Anothcr was despatch
cd and returned without success. A third
was ordered to make the attempt, and con
tracted for clothing the sailors in an admi-
ral's galley. 1t would be unnecessary for
me to say that this expedition was fortunate.
Were rowers likely to fail, drest in garments
of my own fashionings


! A travelling Greek took lodging in my
house. He called himself philosopher,
voyagng in search of knowledge. am
certain it was by seeing me cut out gore
that he learned the square of the hypothe-
muse Of a right angled triangle is equal othe
squares of the base and pendlcuar added
together, for it cannot be doubted for mo-
lment that knew il. Yet the vagabond had
the audacity to assert that he had made the
discovery by the inspiration OF the muses.,
and offered whole hecatomb in canse-
aucncc, while he seliishly concea'ed my
name altogether. Thus the invention, to
which had so we'll founded right, will be
handed down to after ages as the discovery
of Greek vagrant, while |, who ought IN
consequence to have been buried IN the
great pyramid, am shutiled into a paltry
sycamore coffin in common mummy PIT


was walking with this Greek one day,
when saw an Ibis with peculiarly long
bill mrhat IBIS" said ], "looks like my
grandmother, who had very long nose. =
The scoundrelly philosopher took the hlnt
"Your grandmother's SOUL" said he, "has
transmierated into that Ibis; recollect hay,
inc been goose myself was Euphorbus in
the Trojan war" And upon this ebserva-
ton of mine, he built his theory of transmit
grafton. Yet he chose rather to say that ht
learnt it from the Chaldeans or Brachmans
than from me-such is the gratitude of phi
losophers
was not fitted to thrive amidst greedy
selfish, narrsw minded, avaricious race
except myself. there was no honorable mar
in Epypt. The base knaves took advantage
of nv excellent disposition. nv noble gene.
rosity, my astonishing libcrality, my exalted
virtue, and defrauded me. | resolved tt
quit such nest of crocotiles, and made {
dignifed retreat during the night. that
nv purpose might not be frustrated, dis
guised myself as an humble slave, and ac-
companied the ungrateful philosopher as :
servant. My base minded countrymen, ind
ing was out of their reach, vented theil
sorrow in the most horrible .calumnies, ane
said fed for debt. did indeed owe some
individuals money, which did not think i
convenient to pay, but if that was set on a.
rainst the endless debt my country owed t
me. the balance would be found immensely


in my favour.


went with this philosophical quack t.
his native city of Samos: there | clyillzet
the barbarous sIanders---they knew nothing
of fashionable dress till | taught them
From thence accompanied him to Croto
ma; there humanized the people Of Italy
from savages made them one OF the poilt


Al

full articles.headline: On the ranked soul
full articles.article:
The gaming fury falls; and IN ono gulph
Of total ruin, virtue, peace,
Friends, families. and fortune, headlong sink.


Thomson JPinter.
